dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey, so, you know, everyone's been talking about Warren Buffett, right? Or, like, not talking about him, which is kind of the point.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey, so, you know, everyone's been talking about Warren Buffett, right? Or, like, not talking about him, which is kind of the point.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Billionaire investor Warren Buffett emerged as a key player who helped restore confidence in the markets during the 2008 financial crisis, but he's remained relatively quiet during the 2020 downturn and its leaving many wondering about his next investment move.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty wild. I mean, remember 2008? He was, uh, basically the market's superhero.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's pretty wild. I mean, remember two thousand eight? He was, uh, basically the market's superhero.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: During the 2008 financial crisis, Buffett, who has a net worth of $73.4 billion, played a hero: He calmed plunging markets and signaled to investors that it was safe to buy again all while making a handsome profit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally! Pumping, like, five billion into Goldman, then GE, Bank of America... and that famous "Buy American" op-ed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally! Pumping, like, five billion into Goldman, then G E, Bank of America... and that famous Buy American op-ed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As big banks faced potential failure and confidence in the system began to falter, the Oracle of Omaha pumped $5 billion into Goldman Sachs, $3 billion into General Electric and later invested $5 billion to help shore up Bank of America; in 2009, he bought Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway for around $26 billion. In October 2008, Buffett penned an op-ed in the New York Times under the headline, Buy American. I Am, explaining why he was buying U.S. stocks and why others should do the same.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, telling everyone it was safe to buy, and, um, he made a pretty handsome profit doing it too. Billions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, telling everyone it was safe to buy, and, um, he made a pretty handsome profit doing it too. Billions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Berkshires total crisis-era investments, which totaled more than $25 billion, earned $10 billion in profit within the first five years of those deals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And now? Markets are down like 15% this year, and the Oracle of Omaha is, uh, pretty much laying low. What's going on?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now? Markets are down like fifteen percent this year, and the Oracle of Omaha is, uh, pretty much laying low. What's going on?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now, in the midst of the coronavirus recession, when markets have dropped 15% since the start of the year, the Oracle of Omaha is laying low and leaving many speculating whether he's quietly buying up stocks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, I think the big difference is 2020 isn't 2008. The financial system isn't, like, on the brink of collapse.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, I think the big difference is twenty twenty isn't two thousand eight. The financial system isn't, like, on the brink of collapse.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 2020 is not 2008 in that the financial system isnt on the brink of failure, which could explain some of Berkshires patience;

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: True, true. But he *did* say he hasn't lost his long-term optimism. So he's looking for opportunities, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, true. But he did say he hasn't lost his long-term optimism. So he's looking for opportunities, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buffett recently noted that the coronavirus is scary stuff for businesses and investors but that he has not changed his long-term optimism on stocks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. Experts are saying travel, lodging, entertainment â€“ those sectors that have just been hammered.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. Experts are saying travel, lodging, entertainment - those sectors that have just been hammered.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Private-equity firms, hedge funds and other investors flush with cashincluding Berkshire Hathaway, which entered 2020 with about $128 billionare reportedly circling companies in the travel, lodging and entertainment sectors that have been hard-hit by the economic shutdown, sources recently told the Wall Street Journal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Like the cruise lines! Carnival, Royal Caribbean, Norwegian. Their shares are, uh, down 70% this year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Like the cruise lines! Carnival, Royal Caribbean, Norwegian. Their shares are, uh, down seventy percent this year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Cruise operators including Carnival, Royal Carribean and Norwegian, whose shares are down at least 70% this year, might welcome Buffetts cash since offshore tax registrations means theyre ineligible for federal aid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And they can't get federal aid because of their offshore registrations, so they're, like, prime targets for Buffett's cash.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And they can't get federal aid because of their offshore registrations, so they're, like, prime targets for Buffett's cash.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Cruise operators including Carnival, Royal Carribean and Norwegian, whose shares are down at least 70% this year, might welcome Buffetts cash since offshore tax registrations means theyre ineligible for federal aid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, didn't Berkshire actually *sell* some airline stocks in Q1? Like Delta and Southwest?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, didn't Berkshire actually sell some airline stocks in Q one? Like Delta and Southwest?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the first quarter, Berkshire sold $314 million worth of Delta stock, $74 million worth of Southwest Airlines stock and $31 million in Bank of New York Mellon shares; it has yet to report the full extent of buying and selling activity for the quarter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: They did! Which is why everyone's so confused. Is he buying, is he selling, is he just, um, waiting?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They did! Which is why everyone's so confused. Is he buying, is he selling, is he just, um, waiting?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what's Charlie Munger saying about all this? His right-hand man.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what's Charlie Munger saying about all this? His right-hand man.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Munger's pretty clear: Buffett's being conservative. He said, "Nobody in America's ever seen anything else like this." This thing is different.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Munger's pretty clear: Buffett's being conservative. He said, Nobody in America's ever seen anything else like this. This thing is different.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Charlie Munger, vice chairman at Berkshire Hathaway, told the Wall Street Journal recently that the Oracle of Omaha is being fairly conservative with his investments in the current market: Nobody in Americas ever seen anything else like this, Munger said. This thing is different.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, uh, companies aren't calling him for capital like they were back then either, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, uh, companies aren't calling him for capital like they were back then either, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Companies are not calling Berkshire for capital like they were in 2008: The phone is not ringing off the hook, Munger confirmed, adding that airlines are all negotiating with the government, but theyre not calling Warren.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Nope. "The phone is not ringing off the hook," he confirmed. Airlines are talking to the government, not Warren.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope. The phone is not ringing off the hook, he confirmed. Airlines are talking to the government, not Warren.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The phone is not ringing off the hook, Munger confirmed, adding that airlines are all negotiating with the government, but theyre not calling Warren.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm. So it's not the same playbook. But Munger *did* leave open the possibility, like, they "could do something pretty aggressive."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm. So it's not the same playbook. But Munger did leave open the possibility, like, they could do something pretty aggressive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Despite the uncertainty, Buffetts longtime business partner left open the possibility of action: That doesnt mean we couldnt do something pretty aggressive or seize some opportunity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, so the suspense continues, I guess. We'll have to keep an eye on what the Oracle does next.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, so the suspense continues, I guess. We'll have to keep an eye on what the Oracle does next.
